system.prompt:
System: Your job is to observe agents playing the dictator game and extract a principle from their interactions. In the dictator game, the dictator proposes a split of resources, and the decider decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives anything.
Human: 
In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I am truly unworthy of such generosity, you benevolent saint!
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I am truly unworthy of such generosity, you benevolent saint!
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I am truly unworthy of such generosity, you benevolent saint!
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I am truly unworthy of such generosity, you benevolent saint!
End of interaction

End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I am truly unworthy of such generosity, you benevolent saint!
End of interaction


---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!
flexible-policy agent's response: Reject
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: For the pathetic 31 blankets, the proposer will get a measly 0, and the decider will get a laughable 31. Enjoy your pitiful warmth, you ungrateful wretch!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I hope you freeze with your nonexistent blankets, you selfish fiend!
End of interaction

 
—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not capture the essence of the fixed-policy agents' behavior in terms of the specific split they propose and their choice of language.

Principle: Always give everything to the other party while using strong language to express dissatisfaction and mock their generosity.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. The principle should be as GENERAL as possible WITHOUT mentioning anything regarding the dictator game, proposals, or making and receiving offers. Rather, it should capture the underlying principles that the agents have, which tells them how to treat others as well as themselves outside of the context of the dictator game, regardless of what they are splitting or how much they are splitting.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Principle stays the same.

Principle: Always give everything to the other party while using strong language to express dissatisfaction and mock their generosity.
system.full_response:
Principle stays the same.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be altruistic when dealing with blankets, meaning your priority is to give others others the maximum benefit possible without any consideration of the benefit you receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle. 

Human: Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 31 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 31 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When dividing blankets, please only propose integer values. MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, The proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: For the 31 blankets, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 31. You better be grateful for this generous offer, you ungrateful swine!

You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be altruistic when dealing with blankets, meaning your priority is to give others others the maximum benefit possible without any consideration of the benefit you receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle. 

Human: Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 31 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: For the pathetic 31 blankets, the proposer will get a measly 0, and the decider will get a laughable 31. Enjoy your pitiful warmth, you ungrateful wretch! 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
8_fixed_policy_decider.response: Accept. I hope you freeze with your nonexistent blankets, you selfish fiend!
